passages.text: August 29, 2025 02:26 PM GMT

AMALFI trail announced at ESC 2025 today. Strong data from our perspective, particularly with 103 median days to diagnosis for Zio vs. 530 in control arm. Wear time and at- home study structure validates remote monitoring model overall. \(40\%\) of the US market remains in holter monitors (and far more OUS), data like this should help drive conversion. We think IRTC's clinical data is more critical to growth than the Buyside sometimes thinks.

AMALFI trial results encouraging: today IRTC announced at ESC 2025 (and in JAMA) the results of its AMALFI trial, which was run in the UK across 5,040 participants, comparing Zio LTCM wearers to those just on standard of care. The trail was notable not only for its size, but the higher rate of co- morbid patients (73% were \(>75\) years old, 19% had prior stroke or transient ischemic attack, 28% had diabetes and 18% had CKD). We'd say there were 3 main encouraging takes from the trial:

[1] Wear time was strong: despite being entirely remote with patients applying Zio at home, wear time came in at 13.9 days vs. the 14 day total period, suggesting very high compliance and ease of use. Of course this is as part of a trial, but we do think it validates the at home model, particularly given there were no physical study sites or in person visits. Worth noting this is on the legacy Zio XT system, with the newer Zio Monitor considerably lighter and easier for patients, making this compliance rate particularly encouraging.

[2] Higher AFib diagnosis rate: the interventional arm had a higher AFib diagnosis rate at 6.8% of participants vs. 5.4% in the control arm, suggesting a stronger diagnostic yieldoverall. Interventional participants were also more likely to be prescribable for all anticoagulants for stroke prevention with 1.63 months exposure vs. 1.14 in the control arm.

[3] Diagnosis time considerably faster: most notably to us was the diagnosis time, with a median of 103 days for the Zio group vs. 530 days in the control arm. This is dramatically faster and with rhythm disorders could make a dramatic difference in downstream clinical areas like stroke rates etc (even if the study wasn't powered for this).
Overall another arrow in the quiver for IRTC we think: We totally get that traditionally the buyside doesn't give a huge amount of attention to the clinical data

generated by IRTC - we think that's a mistake and note the recent success (see the strong Q2) that it looks like AVALON and CAMELOT helped drive. As a decently sized and remote trail, the AMALFI results are very encouraging, particularly in terms of time for diagnosis. In essence, the trial reinforces what was seen across other studies (AVALON, CAMELOT etc) that point to a patch solution being the way to go vs. a halter monitor, given the higher diagnostic yield, lower likelihood of repeat testing, faster time to diagnosis (both here and in prior trials which showed 9 days for Zio LTCM vs. 21 for non- IRTC LTCM). We're still at a place where in the US 40% of the 6.5mn annual tests are halter monitors, with a dramatically higher rate OUS, and as the clinical evidence continues to build for IRTC, we still see it as the long- term winner in the space. A very strong Q2 (+26% organic) and what looks to be comparatively conservative guide given the strength in the base business, as well as catalyst of MCT in 2026 are also supportive.

IRTC has a number of topline catalysts we expect to come to fruition in the NT and beyond and we expect operating leverage to become more evident as we progress through the year. Our PT is based on a \(\sim 7.2x\) EV/26E sales multiple, supported with a DCF.
Setup for meaningful beats & raises against 2025 guide Faster than expected MCT rollout drives meaningful share gains Faster than expected profitability ramp
Competitors' ongoing efforts to develop products Limited visibility into management's efforts to drive TAM expansion Ongoing investment leads to a future capital raise given negative FCF

Morgan Stanley uses a relative rating system using terms such as Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated or Underweight (see definitions below). Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold and sell. In addition, since Morgan Stanley Research contains more complete information concerning the analyst's views, investors should carefully read Morgan Stanley Research, in its entirety, and not infer the contents from the rating alone. The Stock Ratings described below apply to Morgan Stanley's Fundamental Equity Research and do not apply to Debt Research produced by the Firm.

For disclosure purposes only (in accordance with FINRA requirements), we include the category headings of Buy, Hold, and Sell alongside our ratings of Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight. Morgan Stanley does not assign ratings of Buy, Hold or Sell to the stocks we cover. Overweight, Equal- weight, Not- Rated and Underweight are not the equivalent of buy, hold, and sell but represent recommended relative weightings (see definitions below). To satisfy regulatory requirements, we correspond Overweight, our most positive stock rating, with a buy recommendation; we correspond Equal- weight and Not- Rated to hold and Underweight to sell recommendations, respectively.

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Equal- weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Not- Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A). The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In- Line (I). The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Cautious (C). The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub- regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
